title: Put The Equation In The Correct Form with Zero By Itself On One Side
text: Write the inequality as one quotient on the left and zero on the right.

title: Find The Critical Points of Equation
text: The quotient is $$0$$ when the numerator is $$0$$. Since the numerator is always $$3$$, the quotient cannot be $$0$$.

title: Find The Critical Points of Equation
text: The quotient will be undefined when the denominator is zero. $$\left(x-1\right) \left(x-4\right)=0$$ when $$x=1$$, $$x=4$$.

title: Use the Critical Points to Divide the Number Line into Intervals.
text: Given that the $$x=1$$ and $$x=4$$ are the two critical points, we can divide the number line into three intervals, namely, $$(-\infty,1)$$, $$(1,4)$$ and $$(4,\infty)$$.

title: Test a Value in Each Interval.
text: To find the sign of each factor in an interval, we choose any point in that interval and use it as a test point. Any point in the interval will give the expression the same sign, so we can choose any point in the interval.

title: Test a Value in Each Interval.
text: For the interval $$(4,\infty)$$, take the point $$x=5$$ within the interval and plug it into the original expression $$\frac{1}{\left(x-1\right) \left(x-4\right)}$$. title: Determine the Intervals Where the Inequality is Correct.
